node.title: 'Expect to get checked': Police warn people flying into Queensland from COVID hotspots
node.alt: Bijay Thapa hugs his wife at Brisbane Airport.
node.description: Police say not everyone coming into Queensland from a COVID-19 hotspot to home quarantine will be thoroughly checked at the airport but travellers arriving under new border rules have been told there will be random checks of documents.
node.content: ["Police say not everyone coming into Queensland\u00a0from a COVID-19 hotspot to home quarantine will be thoroughly checked at the airport as\u00a0travellers begin arriving under new border rules.", "More than 140 people have already entered the state under the new pass system which came into force on Monday evening.", "Under the new measures, eligible applicants who meet the home quarantine requirements can receive border passes immediately.", "It comes as the state recorded no new community cases of COVID-19 and one in hotel quarantine.", "Police Deputy Commissioner Steve Gollschewski\u00a0told ABC Radio Brisbane there are more than 1,300 applications in the new home quarantine system.", "Police presence will also be increased across the state's airports to accommodate enforcement of the new rules which allow\u00a0interstate travellers to fly into any airport within two hours' drive of their nominated quarantine residence.", "Passengers are also\u00a0required to be fully vaccinated and present a negative COVID-19 test result from within 72 hours of travel.", "\"Expect to get checked and make sure that you have the evidence with you that you need to have,\" he said.", "\"They're doing an audit of people that come through, sometimes it's 100 per cent and sometimes it's not.", "\"So far up until last night we've had 141 people come in and we currently have 1,319 applications in the system for the new pass and we still have over 12,000 people overall with applications in the system.\"", "The Deputy Commissioner said while levels of compliance had been very high, random audits would still be carried out.", "Police are urging anyone coming into Queensland under the new rules to be mindful of the negative PCR test requirements required within 72 hours.", "\"So as long as people can upload a screenshot of that text message, the system will accept that, but of course we are doing random audits and we will check people and we will make sure that everyone's doing the right thing,\" he said.", "Queensland Health said at-home rapid antigen tests would not be accepted as evidence of a negative test result."]
